default.title: invention
default.definition: The act of inventing; the contriving or creating of something new.
default.contextualMeaning: Something that has been newly created or designed, like a new product or idea.
default.exampleSentence: Marco Polo's journey to Italy was linked to the supposed **invention** of pasta.
default.etymology: From Latin *inventio*, 'discovery, contrivance', from *invenire* 'to find, discover'.

default.title: unspecified
default.definition: Not stated or made known; not determined or fixed.
default.contextualMeaning: Referring to a time or detail that is not precisely identified.
default.exampleSentence: The phrase 'at one point or another' means at some **unspecified** time in the past.

default.title: idiom
default.definition: A group of words established by usage as having a meaning not deducible from those of the individual words.
default.contextualMeaning: A fixed expression or phrase where the meaning is not literal.
default.exampleSentence: To 'push the boundaries' is an **idiom** meaning to challenge normal acceptable behaviour.
default.etymology: From Latin *idioma*, 'a peculiar phraseology', from Greek *idioma* 'peculiarity, peculiar phrase'.

default.title: boundaries
default.definition: A line which marks the limits of an area; limits of what is considered acceptable or possible.
default.contextualMeaning: The limits of acceptable behavior or action, often challenged or extended.
default.exampleSentence: Modern versions of ramen **push the boundaries**, unlike other traditional food.
default.etymology: From Old French *bondre* 'limit', possibly from Latin *bodina* 'boundary mark'.

default.title: acceptable
default.definition: Able to be tolerated or allowed; satisfactory or suitable.
default.contextualMeaning: What is considered normal or permissible behavior or taste.
default.exampleSentence: Pushing the boundaries means to do things which challenge normal **acceptable** behaviour.
default.etymology: From Old French *acceptable*, from Latin *acceptare* 'to take, receive'.

default.title: fresh
default.definition: Not previously known or used; newly made or obtained.
default.contextualMeaning: Referring to food that is newly made or prepared, not dried or preserved.
default.exampleSentence: Some people buy noodles dried in a packet, others make them **fresh** from wheat or rice.

default.title: popular
default.definition: Liked, enjoyed, or admired by many people.
default.contextualMeaning: Widely liked and consumed by a large number of people.
default.exampleSentence: There is little doubt that noodles are **popular** around the world.
default.etymology: From Latin *popularis* 'belonging to the people, common'.

default.title: origins
default.definition: The point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived.
default.contextualMeaning: The geographical place where noodles first appeared.
default.exampleSentence: From their **origins**, probably somewhere in China, noodle recipes were spread.

default.title: recipes
default.definition: Detailed instructions for preparing a particular dish, meal, or drink.
default.contextualMeaning: Instructions for making noodle dishes.
default.exampleSentence: Noodle **recipes** were spread by traders on the ancient Silk Road.
default.etymology: From Latin *recipere* 'to take, receive' (originally medical prescriptions).

default.title: spread
default.definition: Extend over a large or increasing area.
default.contextualMeaning: To be distributed or disseminated over a wide geographical area.
default.exampleSentence: Noodle recipes were **spread** by traders on the ancient Silk Road.

default.title: traders
default.definition: People who buy and sell goods or services.
default.contextualMeaning: Individuals involved in the commercial exchange of goods, like noodles, across regions.
default.exampleSentence: Noodle recipes were **spread** by **traders** on the ancient Silk Road.
default.etymology: From Old French *trade* 'course, track', related to 'tread'.

default.title: destination
default.definition: The place to which someone or something is going or being sent.
default.contextualMeaning: A specific location where noodles or their recipes arrived.
default.exampleSentence: At each **destination** along the road, people gave noodles a twist.

default.title: flavour
default.definition: The distinctive taste of a food or drink; a particular quality or atmosphere.
default.contextualMeaning: The specific taste profile added to noodle dishes.
default.exampleSentence: At each **destination** along the road, people gave noodles a twist, adding different **flavours** and ingredients.

default.title: ingredients
default.definition: Any of the foods or substances that are combined to make a particular dish.
default.contextualMeaning: The components used to make or season noodle dishes.
default.exampleSentence: At each **destination** along the road, people gave noodles a twist, adding different flavours and **ingredients**.
default.etymology: From Latin *ingredientem*, present participle of *ingredi* 'to enter, go into'.

default.title: varieties
default.definition: The quality or state of being different or diverse; a number or collection of different things.
default.contextualMeaning: Different kinds or types of noodles or noodle dishes.
default.exampleSentence: We'll visit the United States and Japan, two countries which have taken noodles and created exciting new **varieties**.

default.title: investigated
default.definition: To carry out a systematic or formal inquiry to discover and examine the facts of (an incident, allegation, etc.) so as to establish the truth.
default.contextualMeaning: Researched or studied how noodles spread.
default.exampleSentence: BBC World Service programme, The Food Chain, **investigated** how noodles spread from Asia through Europe to America.
default.etymology: From Latin *investigare* 'to track or trace out'.

default.title: uncovered
default.definition: To discover (something previously hidden, lost, or unknown).
default.contextualMeaning: Revealed or found out a surprising story.
default.exampleSentence: They **uncovered** a surprising story: that pasta comes from noodles brought back to Italy by Marco Polo.

default.title: exotic
default.definition: Originating in or characteristic of a distant foreign country; strikingly or delightfully unusual or different.
default.contextualMeaning: Unusual and exciting because of coming from far away.
default.exampleSentence: Noodles were very **exotic** in the 1920s and 30s in the United States.

default.title: association
default.definition: A group of people organized for a joint purpose; a connection or cooperative link between people or organizations.
default.contextualMeaning: An organization formed to promote pasta manufacturing.
default.exampleSentence: There was a new pasta **association** in America that wanted to promote the manufacturing of dried pasta.

default.title: promote
default.definition: To further the progress of something; to support or actively encourage.
default.contextualMeaning: To encourage the growth or sale of dried pasta.
default.exampleSentence: A new pasta association in America wanted to **promote** the manufacturing of dried pasta.

default.title: manufacturing
default.definition: The making of articles on a large scale using machinery; the production of something.
default.contextualMeaning: The industrial production of dried pasta.
default.exampleSentence: A new pasta association in America wanted to promote the **manufacturing** of dried pasta.

default.title: meaning
default.definition: What is meant by a word, text, concept, or action.
default.contextualMeaning: The definition or interpretation of a word, as in 'exotic meaning foreign'.
default.exampleSentence: In the 1920s, noodles were popular because they were exotic, **meaning** foreign, unusual and exciting.

default.title: foreign
default.definition: Of, from, or characteristic of a country or language other than one's own.
default.contextualMeaning: Originating from a country other than the United States, making it exotic.
default.exampleSentence: In the 1920s, noodles were popular because they were exotic, meaning **foreign**, unusual and exciting.

default.title: localise
default.definition: To adapt (a product or service) to suit a particular country, area, or culture.
default.contextualMeaning: To adapt Chinese noodle dishes to be more suitable for Japanese taste and culture.
default.exampleSentence: At one point or another, different chefs decided to **localise** these dishes.

default.title: slices
default.definition: Thin, broad pieces of food or other material cut from a larger portion.
default.contextualMeaning: Thin pieces of beef or chicken used as toppings for ramen.
default.exampleSentence: By making these tweaks, adding new toppings and **slices** of beef or chicken, Japanese chefs created the noodle dish we know today as ramen.

default.title: gradually
default.definition: In a slow, continuous, and steady manner; by degrees.
default.contextualMeaning: Developing and changing slowly over time.
default.exampleSentence: Frank thinks that Japanese ramen continues to evolve – to develop and change **gradually** in response to new developments and ideas.
default.etymology: From Late Latin *gradualis* (adv. *gradatim*), from Latin *gradus* 'step, pace'.

default.title: response
default.definition: A verbal or written answer; a reaction to something.
default.contextualMeaning: A development or change occurring as a reaction to new ideas.
default.exampleSentence: Frank thinks that Japanese ramen continues to evolve – to develop and change gradually in **response** to new developments and ideas.

default.title: traditional
default.definition: Existing in or as part of a tradition; long-established.
default.contextualMeaning: Referring to food or practices that have been part of a culture for a long time, often in contrast to modern innovations.
default.exampleSentence: Unlike other **traditional** food such as sushi, modern versions of ramen push the boundaries.
